revision.text:
{{Short description|Synthetic DNA}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2019}} {{Further|Xenobiology}} [[File:DNA animation.gif|thumb|A [[Nucleic acid double helix|double helix]] of natural DNA. Hachimoji DNA adopts a similar structure.|alt=]] '''Hachimoji DNA''' (from [[Japanese language|Japanese]] {{lang|ja|八文字}} ''hachimoji'', "eight letters") is a synthetic [[Nucleic acid analogue|nucleic acid analog]] that uses four synthetic [[nucleotides]] in addition to the four present in the natural [[nucleic acid]]s, DNA and RNA. This leads to four allowed [[base pair]]s: two [[unnatural base pairs]] formed by the synthetic [[nucleobase]]s in addition to the two normal pairs. Hachimoji bases have been demonstrated in both DNA and RNA analogs, using [[deoxyribose]] and [[ribose]] respectively as the backbone sugar.{{cite journal | vauthors = Hoshika S, Leal NA, Kim MJ, Kim MS, Karalkar NB, Kim HJ, Bates AM, Watkins NE, SantaLucia HA, Meyer AJ, DasGupta S, Ellington AD, SantaLucia J, Georgiadis MM, Benner SA | title = Hachimoji DNA and RNA: A genetic system with eight building blocks | journal = Science | volume = 363 | issue = 6429 | pages = 884–887 | date = February 2019 | pmid = 30792304 | pmc = 6413494 | doi = 10.1126/science.aat0971| bibcode = 2019Sci...363..884H }}{{cite news |author=American Association for the Advancement of Science |title=Hachimoji – Expanding the genetic alphabet from four to eight |url=https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2019-02/aaft-h-e021919.php |date=21 February 2019 |work=[[EurekAlert!]] |access-date=22 February 2019|author-link=American Association for the Advancement of Science }}{{cite news |last1=Brown |first1=Dwayne |last2=Landau |first2=Elizabeth | name-list-format = vanc |title=Research creates DNA-like molecule to aid search for alien life |url=https://phys.org/news/2019-02-dna-like-molecule-aid-alien-life.html |date=21 February 2019 |work=[[Phys.org]] |access-date=22 February 2019 }}{{cite news |last=Dumé |first=Bello | name-list-format = vanc |title=Hachimoji DNA doubles the genetic code |url=https://physicsworld.com/a/hachimoji-dna-doubles-the-genetic-code/ |date=22 February 2019 |work=[[Physics World]] |access-date=22 February 2019 }}{{cite news |last=Zimmer |first=Carl | name-list-format = vanc |authorlink=Carl Zimmer |title=DNA Gets a New — and Bigger — Genetic Alphabet - DNA is spelled out with four letters, or bases. Researchers have now built a system with eight. It may hold clues to the potential for life elsewhere in the universe and could also expand our capacity to store digital data on Earth. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/21/science/dna-hachimoji-genetic-alphabet.html |date=21 February 2019 |work=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=21 February 2019 }} Benefits of such a nucleic acid system may include an enhanced ability to [[DNA digital data storage|store data]], as well as insights into what may be possible in the search for [[extraterrestrial life]].{{cite news |last=Dvorsky |first=George | name-list-format = vanc |title=Freaky Eight-Letter DNA Could Be the Stuff Aliens Are Made Of |url=https://gizmodo.com/freaky-eight-letter-dna-could-be-the-stuff-aliens-are-m-1832823430 |date=22 February 2019 |work=[[Gizmodo]] |access-date=23 February 2019 }} The hachimoji DNA system produced one type of catalytic RNA ([[ribozyme]] or [[aptamer]]) ''in vitro''. ==Description== Natural [[DNA]] is a molecule carrying the [[genetics|genetic]] instructions used in the growth, development, functioning, and [[reproduction]] of all known living [[organism]]s and many [[virus]]es. DNA and [[ribonucleic acid]] (RNA) are [[nucleic acid]]s; alongside [[protein]]s, [[lipids]] and complex carbohydrates ([[polysaccharide]]s), nucleic acids are one of the four major types of [[macromolecule]]s that are essential for all known forms of [[life]]. DNA is a [[polynucleotide]] as it is composed of simpler [[monomer]]ic units called [[nucleotide]]s; when double-stranded, the two chains coil around each other to form a [[Nucleic acid double helix|double helix]].{{Cite book |vauthors= Alberts B, Johnson A, Lewis J, Raff M, Roberts K, Walter P |title= Molecular Biology of the Cell |edition= 6th |publisher= Garland |year= 2014 |chapter-url= http://www.garlandscience.com/product/isbn/9780815344322 |chapter= Chapter 4: DNA, Chromosomes and Genomes |isbn= 978-0-8153-4432-2 |url-status= live |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140714210549/http://www.garlandscience.com/product/isbn/9780815344322 |archive-date= 14 July 2014 |df= dmy-all }}{{cite web|last1=Purcell|first1=Adam |name-list-format=vanc |title=DNA| url= http://basicbiology.net/micro/genetics/dna|website=Basic Biology |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170105045651/http://basicbiology.net/micro/genetics/dna/ |archive-date=5 January 2017}} In natural DNA, each nucleotide is composed of one of four [[nucleobase]]s ([[cytosine]] [C], [[guanine]] [G], [[adenine]] [A] or [[thymine]] [T]), a [[monosaccharide|sugar]] called [[deoxyribose]], and a [[Organophosphate|phosphate group]]. The nucleotides are joined to one another in a chain by [[covalent bond]]s between the sugar of one nucleotide and the phosphate of the next, resulting in an alternating [[backbone chain|sugar-phosphate backbone]]. The nitrogenous bases of the two separate polynucleotide strands are bound to each other with [[hydrogen bond]]s, according to [[base pair]]ing rules (A with T and C with G), to make double-stranded DNA. Hachimoji DNA is similar to natural DNA but differs in the number, and type, of nucleobases. Unnatural nucleobases, more [[hydrophobe|hydrophobic]] than [[Nitrogenous base|natural bases]],{{cite journal | vauthors = Warren M | title = Four new DNA letters double life's alphabet | journal = Nature | volume = 566 | issue = 7745 | pages = 436 | date = February 2019 | pmid = 30809059 | doi = 10.1038/d41586-019-00650-8 | bibcode = 2019Natur.566..436W | doi-access = free }}{{cite news |last=Thulin |first=Lila | name-list-format = vanc |title=Scientists Successfully Double the DNA Alphabet - "Hachimoji DNA" is structurally sound, offers new possibilities for data storage and raises questions about the molecular makeup potential alien life |url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/scientists-just-doubled-number-letters-dna-alphabet-180971552/ |date=25 February 2019 |work=[[Smithsonian (magazine)|Smithsonian Magazine]] |access-date=25 February 2019 }} are used in successful hachimoji DNA. Such a DNA always formed the [[Nucleic acid double helix|standard double helix]], no matter what sequence of bases were used. An [[enzyme]] ([[T7 DNA polymerase|T7 polymerase]]) was adapted by the researchers to be used ''in vitro'' to [[Transcription (biology)|transcribe]] hachimoji DNA into hachimoji RNA, which, in turn, produced chemical activity in the form of a glowing green [[fluorophore]]. ===New base pairs=== DNA and RNA are naturally composed of four nucleotide bases that form hydrogen bonds in order to pair. Hachimoji DNA uses an additional four synthetic nucleotides to form four types of base pairs, two of which are unnatural: '''P''' binds with '''Z''' and '''B''' binds with '''S''' ('''dS''' in [[DNA]], '''rS''' in [[RNA]]). :{| {{Table|class=center}} ! colspan="2"| [[Nucleobase|Base]] !! [[Chemical nomenclature|Name]] || [[Chemical formula#Molecular formula|Formula]] || [[SMILES]] !! [[Chemical structure|Structure]] || [[ChemSpider]] !! [[PubChem]] |- ! colspan="2"|'''P''' | [[5-Aza-7-deazaguanine|2-Aminoimidazo[1,2a][1,3,5]triazin-4(1''H'')-one]]
{{small|2-amino-8-(1′-b-D-2′-deoxyribofuranosyl)-imidazo-[1,2a]-1,3,5-triazin-[8H]-4-one}} | C5H5N5O | {{mono|1=C1=CN2C(=O)NC(=NC2=N1)N}} | [[File:5-aza-7-deazaguanine.svg|frameless|75px|center]] | [http://www.chemspider.com/Chemical-Structure.10205066.html 10205066] | [https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/135600909 135600909] |- ! colspan="2"|'''Z''' | [[6-Amino-5-nitropyridin-2-one]]
{{small|6-amino-3-(1′-b-D-2′-deoxyribofuranosyl)-5-nitro-1H-pyridin-2-one}} | C5H5N3O3 | {{mono|1=C1=CC(=O)NC(=C1[N+](=O)[O-])N}} | [[File:6-Amino-5-nitropyridin-2-one.svg|frameless|50px|center]] | [http://www.chemspider.com/Chemical-Structure.9357814.html 9357814] | [https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/11182729 11182729] |- style="border-top:solid #ccc;" ! colspan="2"|'''B''' | [[Isoguanine]]
{{small|6-amino-9[(1′-b-D-2′-deoxyribofuranosyl)-4-hydroxy-5-(hydroxymethyl)-oxolan-2-yl]-1H-purin-2-one}} | C5H5N5O | {{mono|1=C1=NC2=NC(=O)NC(=C2N1)N}} | [[File:Isoguanine vector.svg|frameless|50px|center]] | [http://www.chemspider.com/Chemical-Structure.69351.html 69351] | [https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/76900 76900] |- ! rowspan="2"|'''S''' ! '''rS''' | [[Isocytosine]] | C4H5N3O | {{mono|1=C1=CN=C(NC1=O)N}} | [[File:Isocytosine.png|frameless|50px|center]] | [http://www.chemspider.com/Chemical-Structure.60309.html 60309] | [https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/66950 66950] |- ! '''dS''' | [[1-Methylcytosine]]
{{small| 3-methyl-6-amino-5-(1′-b-D-2′-deoxyribofuranosyl)-pyrimidin-2-one}} | C5H7N3O | {{mono|1=CN1C=CC(=NC1=O)N}} | [[File:1-Methylcytosine.svg|frameless|50px|center]] | [http://www.chemspider.com/Chemical-Structure.71474.html 71474] | [https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/79143 79143] |} {{multiple image | align = center | total_width = 900 | image1 = Hachimoji DNA base pairs.gif | alt1 = Hachimoji DNA | caption1 = | image2 = Hachimoji RNA base pairs.gif | alt2 = Hachimoji RNA | caption2 = | footer =
Base pairings in hachimoji DNA (left, dR = [[deoxyribose]]) and hachimoji RNA (right, R = [[ribose]]).
The natural bases are in the upper row; the unnatural, synthetic bases are in the lower row.
Hydrogen bonds are dashed green lines, with acceptor atoms in red.
}} {{Clear}} ===Background=== Earlier, the research group responsible for the hachimoji DNA system, headed by [[Harvard University]] chemist [[Steven A. Benner|Steven Benner]], had studied a [[Nucleic acid analogue|synthetic DNA analog]] system, named [[Artificially Expanded Genetic Information System]] (AEGIS), that used twelve different nucleotides, including the four found in DNA.{{cite journal | vauthors = Yang Z, Hutter D, Sheng P, Sismour AM, Benner SA | title = Artificially expanded genetic information system: a new base pair with an alternative hydrogen bonding pattern | journal = Nucleic Acids Research | volume = 34 | issue = 21 | pages = 6095–101 | date = 29 October 2006 | pmid = 17074747 | pmc = 1635279 | doi = 10.1093/nar/gkl633 }}{{cite journal | vauthors = Benner SA, Hutter D, Sismour AM | title = Synthetic biology with artificially expanded genetic information systems. From personalized medicine to extraterrestrial life | journal = Nucleic Acids Research. Supplement | volume = 3 | issue = 3 | pages = 125–6 | date = 1 September 2003 | pmid = 14510412 | url = http://nass.oxfordjournals.org/content/3/1/125.long | doi=10.1093/nass/3.1.125}}{{cite journal | vauthors = Benner SA | title = Defining life | journal = Astrobiology | volume = 10 | issue = 10 | pages = 1021–30 | date = December 2010 | pmid = 21162682 | pmc = 3005285 | doi = 10.1089/ast.2010.0524 | bibcode = 2010AsBio..10.1021B }}{{cite news|last1=Klotz|first1=Irene | name-list-format = vanc |title=Synthetic life form grows in Florida lab |url= http://www.nbcnews.com/id/29430688/ |access-date=27 February 2019|work=Science|date=27 February 2009}}{{cite news |last1=Lloyd |first1=Robin | name-list-format = vanc |title=New Artificial DNA Points to Alien Life |url= http://www.livescience.com/3332-artificial-dna-points-alien-life.html |access-date=27 February 2019 |work=LiveScience |date=14 February 2009}} ==Biology== [[Scripps Research]] chemist [[Floyd E. Romesberg|Floyd Romesberg]], noted for creating the first [[Base pair#Unnatural base pair (UBP)|Unnatural Base Pair (UBP)]], and expanding the genetic alphabet of four letters to six in 2012,{{cite journal | vauthors = Malyshev DA, Dhami K, Quach HT, Lavergne T, Ordoukhanian P, Torkamani A, Romesberg FE | title = Efficient and sequence-independent replication of DNA containing a third base pair establishes a functional six-letter genetic alphabet | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 109 | issue = 30 | pages = 12005–10 | date = July 2012 | pmid = 22773812 | pmc = 3409741 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1205176109 | bibcode = 2012PNAS..10912005M }} stated that the invention of the hachimoji DNA system is an example of the fact that the natural bases (G, C, A and T) "are not unique".{{cite news |last=Saplakoglu |first=Yasemin | name-list-format = vanc |title=Scientists Have Created Synthetic DNA with 4 Extra Letters |url=https://www.livescience.com/64829-hachimoji-dna.html |date=21 February 2019 |work=[[Live Science]] |access-date=22 February 2019 }} Creating new life forms may be possible, at least theoretically, with the new DNA system.{{cite news |last=Molteni |first=Megan | name-list-format = vanc |title=Doubling Our DNA Building Blocks Could Lead To New Life Forms |url=https://www.wired.com/story/doubling-our-dna-building-blocks-could-lead-to-new-life-forms/ |date=21 February 2019 |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |access-date=22 February 2019 }} For now, however, the hachimoji DNA system is not self-sustaining; the system needs a steady supply of unique building blocks and proteins found only in the laboratory. As a result, "Hachimoji DNA can go nowhere if it escapes the laboratory." ==Applications== [[NASA]] funded this research to "expand[s] the scope of the structures that we might encounter as we search for life in the cosmos". According to [[Lori Glaze]] of the Planetary Science Division of NASA, "Life detection is an increasingly important goal of NASA's planetary science missions, and this new work [with hachimoji DNA] will help us to develop effective instruments and experiments that will expand the scope of what we look for."{{cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2019/02/21/world/synthetic-dna-alien-life/index.html|title=Synthetic DNA could help with search for alien life|last=Stickland|first=Ashley | name-list-format = vanc |date=21 February 2019|work=[[CNN News]]|access-date=22 February 2019}} Research team leader [[Steven Benner]] notes, "By carefully analyzing the roles of shape, size and structure in hachimoji DNA, this work expands our understanding of the types of [[molecule]]s that might store information in extraterrestrial life on alien worlds."{{cite news|url=https://www.iflscience.com/chemistry/new-artificial-dna-has-doubled-the-alphabet-of-life|title=New Artificial DNA Has Doubled The Alphabet Of Life |last=Carpineti |first=Alfredo | name-list-format = vanc |date=22 February 2019 |work=[[Elise Andrew|IFLScience.com]] |access-date=22 February 2019 }} According to researchers, hachimoji DNA could also be used "to develop clean [[diagnostic]]s for [[human disease]]s, in [[DNA digital data storage]], [[DNA barcoding]], self-assembling [[nanostructure]]s, and to make [[protein]]s with unusual [[amino acid]]s. Parts of this hachimoji DNA are already being commercially produced by Firebird Biomolecular Sciences LLC". == See also == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Abiogenesis]] * [[Astrobiology]] * [[Carbon chauvinism]] * [[Carbon-based life]] * [[Center for Life Detection Science]] * [[Earliest known life forms]] * [[Extraterrestrial life]] * [[Human Nature (2019 film)|''Human Nature'' (2019 CRISPR film documentary)]] * [[Hypothetical types of biochemistry]] * [[Nucleic acid analogue]] * [[xDNA]] {{div col end}} == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * {{cite journal | vauthors = Bains W | title = Many chemistries could be used to build living systems | journal = Astrobiology | volume = 4 | issue = 2 | pages = 137–67 | date = 2004 | pmid = 15253836 | doi = 10.1089/153110704323175124 | url = http://www.ifa.hawaii.edu/~meech/a281/handouts/Baines_astrobio04.pdf | bibcode = 2004AsBio...4..137B }} Hypothesis paper. == External links == * [http://www.faqs.org/faqs/astronomy/faq/part6/section-16.html Astronomy FAQ - Why do we assume that other beings must be based on carbon? Why couldn't organisms be based on other substances?] * {{youtube|yWqlwYjpc1A|Film clip encoded into DNA using CRISPR: video (01:39)}} {{Genetics}} {{Gene expression}} {{Nucleic acids}} {{Astrobiology}} {{Portal bar|Astronomy|Biology|Technology}} [[Category:Astrobiology]] [[Category:Biotechnology]] [[Category:Biological contamination]] [[Category:DNA]] [[Category:Genetically modified organisms]] [[Category:Genetic engineering]] [[Category:Invasive species]] [[Category:Helices]]
